questions.text: Choose the correct pathogen based on the cell wall shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Cell wall of Aspergillus fumigates is almost exclusively composed of polysaccharides. The fibriller core is composed of a branched B 1,3 glucan to which chitin, B ( 1,3)-/B- (1,4)- glucan and galactomannan are covalently bound.

In the given image all these structures are present.

So this is cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus

Incorrect Options:

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Choice A): Has a mycolic acid-rich cell wall, which gives it a waxy, acid-fast property.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Choice B): Lacks a cell wall, making it resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • Rhinosporidium seeberi (Choice C): A fungus-like organism with a thick-walled sporangium, but its cell wall composition differs from Aspergillus fumigatus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Aspergillus fumigatus has a polysaccharide-rich cell wall with β-glucans, chitin, and galactomannan.
  • The cell wall composition is crucial for antifungal drug targeting.
  • Unlike Mycobacterium tuberculosis (which has mycolic acid), Mycoplasma pneumoniae (which lacks a cell wall), and Rhinosporidium seeberi (which has a different structure), Aspergillus fumigatus has a characteristic fungal cell wall.

choices.text: Collect by using cardboard and put in water
Collect by using your hand and wash your hand
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Collect by using broom and discard in dustbin

questions.text: Choose the correct management of mercury spill from sphygmomanometer
questions.solution:
Steps for mercury spill

  1. Immediately isolate the spill and ventilate the area
  2. Keep all employees away form spill area
  3. Immediately open windows and exterior doors
  4. Close all interior doors between the room where mercury was spilled and the rest of the work area
  5. Collect it by using card board and put in water

questions.text: Which of the following need not be screened before transfusion?
questions.solution:
Blood transfusion is the most common transplant of tissur.

We have to match only blood groups of patients.

Any healthy person with specific wt can donate the blood.

But there are certain disease which can be transmitted through blood transfusion like HIV, Syphilis, Malaria, Hepatitis B , Hepatitis C

Dengue is not transmitted through blood transfusion.

Incorrect Options:

  • HIV (Choice A): A blood borne virus that can cause AIDS; mandatory screening is required before transfusion.
  • Malaria (Choice B): A parasitic infection caused by Plasmodium species, which can be transmitted via transfusion; hence, screening is required.
  • Syphilis (Choice D): A bacterial infection caused by Treponema pallidum; it can be transmitted through contaminated blood, making screening essential.

Key Takeaways:

  • HIV, Malaria, and Syphilis must be screened before blood transfusion.
  • Dengue is not a transfusion-transmissible disease, hence screening is not necessary.
  • Strict blood screening protocols prevent transfusion-related infections.

questions.text: Biopsy from warty lesion of foot shown in image. Choose the diagnostic form from the image.
questions.solution:
Sclerotic bodies ( Medlar bodies/ muriform bodies/copper pennies) are extruded transepidermal and they appear as black dots on the surface of lesion.

This is characteristic of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by several different dematiaceous fungi ( Brown pigment producing) resulting in the formation of slow growing warty plaques, cauliflower like lesions which may ulcerate.

Infection occurs as a result of traumatic injury and inoculation of microorganism from a specific group of dematiaceous fungi.

Incorrect Options:

  • Budding yeast (Choice A): Seen in fungal infections like Candida spp., Cryptococcus neoformans, and Histoplasma capsulatum. These do not form sclerotic bodies.
  • Asteroid body (Choice B): A characteristic feature of Sporothrix schenckii, seen in sporotrichosis. It consists of a central yeast cell surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material.
  • Negri body (Choice C): Found in rabies virus infection, appearing as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the brain (especially the hippocampus and Purkinje cells).

Key Takeaways:

  • Sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) are diagnostic of chromoblastomycosis.
  • Chromoblastomycosis presents as slow-growing warty, plaque-like lesions.
  • It is caused by traumatic inoculation of dematiaceous fungi.
  • Other structures like budding yeast, asteroid bodies, and Negri bodies are associated with different infections.

questions.text: What is not a AIDS defining malignancy?
questions.solution:
AIDS is caused by HIV virus. There are many opportunistic infections that occur in AIDS and some are malignancies.

AIDS defining malignancy is a type of cancer that a person infected with HIV is at high risk of developing. If a person with HIV develops one of these cancer it means they have AIDS. AIDS defining cancer include Kaposi sarcoma, certain type of non Hodgkin lymphoma and cervical cancer.

Malignant melanoma is not AIDS defining malignancy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (Choice A): One of the most common AIDS-associated cancers, particularly primary CNS lymphoma.
  • Invasive cervical cancer (Choice B): Strongly linked to HPV infection, it is an AIDS-defining malignancy in women.
  • Kaposi sarcoma (Choice C): Highly associated with HIV/AIDS, caused by HHV-8.

Key Takeaways:

  • AIDS-defining malignancies include Kaposi sarcoma, certain types of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and invasive cervical cancer.
  • Malignant melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy.
  • HIV increases the overall risk of cancer due to immune suppression, but not all cancers are AIDS-defining.

Mollicute is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The word Mollicutes is derived from latinmollis and cutis. Individuals are very small, typically only 0.2-0.3 micron in size and have a very small genome size.

Lower classification - mycoplasma, phytoplasma, ureaplasma

Higher classification - firmicutes

Mollicute are smallest and simplest known free living and self replicating form of life.

They are bacteria of gram positive origin as indicated by their 16r RNA.

Diseases caused by mollicutes are erysipelothrix, mycoplasma, and ureaplasma.

Incorrect Options:

  • Chlamydophila pneumoniae (Choice B): A Gram-negative intracellular pathogen causing respiratory infections, including pneumonia and bronchitis.
  • Chlamydia trachomatis (Choice C): A Gram-negative intracellular bacterium causing trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), and urogenital infections.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (Choice D): A Gram-negative obligate intracellular bacterium causing scrub typhus, transmitted by mite larvae (chiggers).

Key Takeaways:

  • Mollicutes lack a cell wall, making them resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • Ureaplasma and Mycoplasma are the main pathogenic Mollicutes.
  • Chlamydia, Chlamydophila, and Orientia are intracellular bacteria but not Mollicutes.

questions.text: Choose the Non acid fast staining organism
questions.solution:
Acid fast bacteria, also known as acid fast bacilli (AFB), are a group of bacteria sharing the characteristic of acid fastness. Acid fastness is a physical property that gives a bacterium the ability to resist decolorization by acids during staining procedures.

Acid fastness is due to high mycolic acid content in cell wall.

M tuberculosis, M leprae, M avium, M bovis, Nocardia, RhodococcusEqui are acid fast bacteria. In parasite C parvum, C belli are acid fast.

Head of sperm is also acid fast.

Incorrect Options:

  • Nocardia (Choice A): Partially acid-fast due to shorter mycolic acid chains compared to Mycobacteria.
  • leprae (Choice B): Fully acid-fast, responsible for leprosy (Hansen's disease).
  • Cryptosporidium parvum / Cystoisospora belli (Choice D): Acid-fast protozoa causing diarrheal illness.

Correct Option:

  • Actinomycetes (Choice C): Non-acid-fast Gram-positive filamentous bacteria. They resemble fungi and are responsible for diseases like Actinomycosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acid-fastness is due to mycolic acid in the bacterial cell wall.
  • Mycobacteria, Nocardia (partially), and Cryptosporidium are acid-fast.
  • Actinomycetes are NOT acid-fast despite being filamentous bacteria.

questions.text: Choose the correct pathogen based on the lifecycle shown in the image.
questions.solution:
This is life cycle of strongyloides stercoralis. This parasitic infection is common in immunocompromised patients.

Strongyloidesstercoralis free living adults. In environment, rhabditiform larvae may develop into infective filariform larvae ( direct cycle) or free living male and female adult worms ( Indirect cycle). Free living adult male measure upto 0.75 mm long, fee living females measure up to 1 mm long.

Strongyloides causes auto infection also.

Incorrect Options:

  • Ancylostoma duodenale (Choice A):
    • Causes hookworm infection.
    • Life cycle involves skin penetration, but it does not have autoinfection or a free-living adult stage.
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (Choice C):
    • Causes intestinal ascariasis.
    • Life Cycle involves ingestion of eggs, followed by larval migration through lungs.
    • No skin penetration or free-living form.
  • Enterobius vermicularis (Choice D):
    • Causes pinworm infection(common in children).
    • Life Cycle involves fecal-oral transmission, with eggs hatching in the intestine.
    • No skin penetration or autoinfection via larvae.

Key Takeaways:

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is unique because it has a free-living form, direct & indirect cycles, and autoinfection.
  • Causes hyperinfection in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Different from hookworms, Ascaris, and Enterobius in terms of transmission & life cycle.

choices.text: Eating water plant is the source of infection

questions.text: Based on the image, choose the correct statement regarding the pathogen.
questions.solution:
This parasite looks like H. nana. It is also known as Dwarf tape worm. It is a cosmopolitan species through most common in temperate zone, and is one of the most common cestode infecting human, specially children.

H nana is only 15 to 40 mm long. It differs from other tapeworm because it requires only one host. But can also cycle two.

This parasitic disease occurs In areas where hygiene is not good.

It is a leaf shaped parasite. (Choice B)

Eating water plants is a source of infection. (Choice D)

H nana causes anemia in children, it can also cause diarrhea, wt loss, fever and eosinophilia. It is treated with Albendazole (Choice A)

So option c is wrong.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hymenolepis nana is the most common tapeworm in children.
  • Transmission is fecal-oral or via infected insects.
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but heavy infections cause GI symptoms.
  • Praziquantel, not Albendazole, is the preferred treatment.
  • It is not leaf-shaped and does not spread through water plants.

choices.text: Pneumocystis prophylaxis mandatory if CD4 COUNT IS <200
Cryptococcus prophylaxis mandatory if CD4 COUNT IS <100
CMV prophylaxis mandatory if CD4 COUNT IS <50
Pneumocystis prophylaxis mandatory if CD4 COUNT IS >350

questions.solution:
AIDS is caused by HIV. In this patients immune system Is affected.

Because HIV attacks CD4 helper cells.

As HIV infection progress CD4 cell count starts decreasing.

Normal CD 4 cell are around 800.

As this count goes down, some infection start occurring.

There are specific guides or prophylaxis is to be started.

Pneumocystis prophylaxis is mandatory if CD4 cell count is below 200 (Choice A)

Cryptococcus prophylaxis is mandatory if CD 4 cell count is below 100 (Choice B)

CMV prophylaxis is mandatory if CD4 cell count is less than 50 (Choice C)

Option D is wrong.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumocystis prophylaxis: CD4 < 200
  • Cryptococcus prophylaxis: CD4 < 100
  • CMV prophylaxis: CD4 < 50
  • No prophylaxis required if CD4 > 350

questions.text: Which is used as disinfectant for artificial products?
questions.solution:
Methyl paraben prevents fungal growth. Thanks to its antibacterial properties, is a preservative that is added to many creams and cosmetic products to prevent fungus from growing .

Methyl paraben has antibacterial activity also. It has antibacterial activity just as polyphenols and involves disruption of cytoplasmic membrane and cytoplasmic membrane and interference with essential enzymes such as ATPase.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

  • (Choice A ): Hydrogen peroxide:
    • Used as a disinfectant and antiseptic for wounds and surfaces.
    • Works by releasing oxygen radicals, which damage microbial cell components.
    • Not commonly used for artificial products.
  • (Choice B) : Bleaching powder:
    • Contains calcium hypochlorite, which acts as a strong oxidizing disinfectant.
    • Used for water purification, surface disinfection, and sanitation.
    • Not suitable for use in artificial or cosmetic products.
  • (Choice C) : Penicillin:
    • An antibiotic that kills bacteria by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.
    • Used for treating bacterial infections, not as a disinfectant.
    • Ineffective for preserving artificial products.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hydrogen peroxide and bleaching powder are strong disinfectants, but not for artificial products.
  • Penicillin is an antibiotic, not a disinfectant.
  • Methyl paraben is specifically used to prevent microbial growth in artificial products.

Reference: www.byrdie.com

questions.text:
Which virus undergo genetic reassortment as influenza virus
A.
B.
C.
D.
questions.solution:
Genetic reassortment, the mixing of genes between two organism to make a new genetic sequence known as a recombinant. Is a powerful mechanism for evolution and adaptation. Sexual reproduction genetically combines the genes of each parent. Each human is a recombinant of the parents genes.

Virus reassortment or simply reassortment is a process of genetic recombination that is exclusive to segmented RNA viruses in which co infection of a host cell with multiple viruses may result in the shuffling of gene segments to generate progeny viruses with novel genome combinations.

Reassortment has been observed in Bunyaviridae, Reoviruses, arenavirus and orthomyxoviruses.

So among given options option A is correct answer.

choices.text: PIR - lag period - 4 to 7 days; SIR- lag period- 1-2 days
PIR-antibody affinity high ; SIR-antibody affinity low

questions.solution:
There are many differences between Primary immune response and Secondary immune response.

In primary immune response IgM are increased.

In secondary immune response IgG are increased.

In primary immune response there is a lag period of 4-7 days. In secondary immune response there is a lag of 1-2 days.

Primary immune response is short lived, While secondary immune response is prolonged.

Option C is wrong that in primary immune response antibody affinity is high and in secondary immune response antibody affinity is low.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

  • Choice A: PIR-IgM; SIR-IgG This is correct. In primary immune response, IgM is the first antibody produced. In secondary immune response, IgG predominates due to memory B cell activation.
  • Choice B: PIR - lag period - 4 to 7 days; SIR- lag period- 1-2 days This is correct. The primary immune response has a longer lag phase (4-7 days) as naive B cells require activation. In contrast, the secondary immune response has a shorter lag period (1-2 days) due to the presence of memory B cells.
  • Choice D: PIR-Short lived; SIR - Prolonged. This is correct. The primary immune response is weaker and short-lived, whereas the secondary immune response is stronger and long-lasting due to memory cell activation.

Key Takeaway:

The primary immune response is characterized by a longer lag phase, production of IgM, and lower antibody affinity, whereas the secondary immune response has a shorter lag phase, predominantly involves IgG, and results in higher antibody affinity due to affinity maturation.

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC I activates
questions.solution:
There are 3 types of MHC. MHC I, MHC II and MHC III

MHC stands for Major histocompatibility complex.

It is also known as HLA ( human leucocyte antigen).

It has major role in graft rejection. All cells have MHC I or MHC II except RBCs.

Antigen binding and processing done by MHC I and MHC II depending on whether the intracellular antigen is there or extracellular antigen is there.

For MHC I Cytotoxic T cell are involved, for MHC II B cells are involved.

MHC I or II does not stimulate Helper T cell or NK Cells.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: B cell B cells are primarily involved in humoral immunity and recognize antigens via their surface immunoglobulin receptors. They are activated by MHC II-restricted antigen presentation, not MHC I, which is associated with cytotoxic T cell activation.

Choice C: Helper T cell Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented on MHC II molecules, which are expressed on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and B cells. MHC I does not activate Helper T cells.

Choice D: NK cell Natural Killer (NK) cells do not require antigen presentation through MHC I for activation. Instead, they target cells that lack MHC I expression, a characteristic feature of some virally infected or cancerous cells. Their activation is regulated by inhibitory and activating signals rather than antigen-MHC interactions.

Key Takeaway:

MHC I presents intracellular antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, leading to targeted cell destruction. In contrast, MHC II presents extracellular antigens to CD4+ helper T cells, which aid in immune response coordination.

questions.text: Which of the following need airborne contact preventing isolation in hospital?
questions.solution:
Measles is a paramyxovirus - enveloped ssRNA virus

Only source of infection is a case of measles, Carrier are not known to occur.

Infective period - 4 days before and 5 days after appearance of rash

Infective material - secretion of nose, throat and respiratory tract

Age group - 6 months to 3 year

C/F

Prodromal stage - fever, coryza with sneezing and nasal discharge, redness of eye, lacrimation, photophobia

A day or two before the appearance of rash, Koplik spot appear on buccal mucosa opp 1st and 2nd lower molar tooth

Eruptive phase - maculopapular rash which begins behind the ear and spreads rapidly in a few hours over the face and neck extends down the body.

Post measle stage - Wt loss, growth retardation ,diarrhea

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)- CJD is caused by prions and is not transmitted via airborne droplets. It is primarily transmitted through contaminated surgical instruments, corneal transplants, or ingestion of infected tissue, not through the respiratory route. Standard precautions, rather than airborne isolation, are used.

Choice B: Nipah Virus- Nipah virus is transmitted through direct contact with infected body fluids, contaminated food, or respiratory droplets, but it does not require strict airborne isolation. Instead, droplet and contact precautions are recommended in hospital settings.

Choice D: Aseptic Meningitis- Aseptic meningitis is usually caused by viruses (such as enteroviruses, mumps virus, or herpesviruses) and is not transmitted through airborne particles. It primarily spreads via the fecal-oral or respiratory droplet route, requiring standard or droplet precautions rather than airborne isolation.

Key Takeaway:

Among the given options, only measles requires airborne isolation due to its high transmissibility through respiratory droplets that remain suspended in the air for prolonged periods. Other diseases listed primarily require standard or droplet precautions.

questions.text: A patient is tested positive for rk39ag test. Choose the correct treatment.
questions.solution:
Rk39 test is used to diagnose invasive fungal disease.Invasive fungal disease are caused by candida albicans, aspergillus fumigatus, cryptococcus neoformans, pneumocystis jiroveci, endemic dimorphic fungi, mucormycetes.

Treatment of invasive fungal disease echinocandin ( Caspofungin, micafungin or anidulafungin) given through IV.

Fluconazole, amphotericin B and other antifungal medications may also be appropriate in certain situations.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Fluconazole - Fluconazole is an antifungal medication primarily used for Candida infections and cryptococcal meningitis, not for visceral leishmaniasis. It is ineffective against Leishmania donovani.

Choice C: Miltefosine - Although miltefosine is an oral drug used for treating visceral leishmaniasis, it is not the preferred first-line therapy in all cases. Liposomal Amphotericin B remains the treatment of choice, especially in severe cases or where resistance to miltefosine is a concern.

Choice D: Sodium Stibogluconate - While sodium stibogluconate was historically used for visceral leishmaniasis, resistance to this drug has emerged in many regions, particularly in India, making it less favorable compared to Liposomal Amphotericin B.

Key Takeaway:

The rk39 antigen test is a specific diagnostic test for visceral leishmaniasis, not an invasive fungal disease. Liposomal Amphotericin B is the preferred treatment due to its efficacy, lower toxicity, and widespread recommendation by WHO.
